- Long long ago, we had brainstorm sessions with our scientists
to learn about lots of cool stories about heat and organisms that had to deal with hot environments and cold environments.
We actually have a whole section about heat, but a lot of the coolest heat stories really depended on seeing the environment
to make sense out of the story, like, sort of the deep cold of the ocean and things like that.
So we realized that maybe a good way to deal with this would be to put a lot of these stories into one Heat Theater experience.
- What is your favorite part of the Heat Theater? Like, what about it makes—gets you excited?
- Well, I'm really excited about how immersive it's going to be.
Long, long ago when we were kind of pitching the idea to the video producers, I had said, you know, "I almost want it to be like a 4D theater."
Something where, like, you could feel how hot it is and feel how cold it is.
Something that can make you feel like you're in the environment with these organisms that have to deal with hot places and cold places.
And they've really done a great job of trying to find ways to do that within the limits of what we can actually do with a traveling exhibit.
So there's going to be sort of tricks of light, and the way it's shaped, and things like that
are all to help enhance the sense of being immersed in these environments.
